unnormalised: Okay folks, let's talk utility bills, yeah? I know, thrilling stuff, right? But honestly, keeping an eye on these expenses can save you a good chunk of change, especially in a city like Mumbai where everything's already so pricey.
normalised: Okay folks, let's talk utility bills, yeah? I know, thrilling stuff, right? But honestly, keeping an eye on these expenses can save you a good chunk of change, especially in a city like Mumbai where everything's already so pricey.

unnormalised: So, I was just going through my bills for last month, October, and man, was I in for a surprise! My electricity bill from Adani Electricity came to a whopping Rs. 4500! Last month it was around Rs. 3000. I thought, “What gives, ya?" Had to double-check everything, even considered calling them up.
normalised: So, I was just going through my bills for last month, October, and man, was I in for a surprise! My electricity bill from Adani Electricity came to a whopping rupee four thousand five hundred! Last month it was around rupee three thousand. I thought, “What gives, ya?" Had to double-check everything, even considered calling them up.

unnormalised: Turns out, my mum had been using the AC practically non-stop, you know, with the October heat still lingering around. Plus, that Diwali cleaning spree meant the washing machine was working overtime. Gotta love family, right? ;)
normalised: Turns out, my mum had been using the A-C practically non-stop, you know, with the October heat still lingering around. Plus, that Diwali cleaning spree meant the washing machine was working overtime. Gotta love family, right?

unnormalised: Then there's the good old Mahanagar Gas bill. That one usually stays pretty consistent, around Rs. 800 or so. We use it for cooking, and thankfully, we've switched to more efficient habits. Small victories, people, small victories!
normalised: Then there's the good old Mahanagar Gas bill. That one usually stays pretty consistent, around rupee eight hundred or so. We use it for cooking, and thankfully, we've switched to more efficient habits. Small victories, people, small victories!

unnormalised: And let's not forget the internet. I'm with JioFiber, and the monthly bill is Rs. 999 + GST, which roughly translates to 1180 INR. It’s relatively stable, but during lockdown last year it used to be much more, with so much WFH! Though sometimes I wonder if I should switch to Airtel – heard good things about their plans.
normalised: And let's not forget the internet. I'm with JioFiber, and the monthly bill is rupee nine hundred and ninety nine plus G-S-T, which roughly translates to one thousand one hundred and eighty I-N-R. It’s relatively stable, but during lockdown last year it used to be much more, with so much W-F-H! Though sometimes I wonder if I should switch to Airtel – heard good things about their plans.

unnormalised: Water bill from BMC is always a mystery, isn’t it? I usually get it quarterly. Last quarter I paid ₹1200. I keep thinking to install rain water harvesting system, but never got around to it, you know how it is.
normalised: Water bill from B-M-C is always a mystery, isn’t it? I usually get it quarterly. Last quarter I paid rupee one thousand two hundred. I keep thinking to install rain water harvesting system, but never got around to it, you know how it is.

unnormalised: Speaking of consistent bills, I also pay 2500 INR for my society maintenance charges. It covers security, building upkeep, and all that jazz. In Bombay, you're pretty much paying for the privilege of not having to worry about certain things, lol.
normalised: Speaking of consistent bills, I also pay two thousand five hundred I-N-R for my society maintenance charges. It covers security, building upkeep, and all that jazz. In Bombay, you're pretty much paying for the privilege of not having to worry about certain things, laugh out loud.

unnormalised: Now, here's a tip I picked up from my chacha (uncle) – keep a spreadsheet! Seriously, tracking your utility expenses month by month can reveal some pretty interesting trends. You can spot spikes and dips, identify potential issues (like my mum’s AC addiction!), and ultimately, find ways to save money.
normalised: Now, here's a tip I picked up from my chacha (uncle) – keep a spreadsheet! Seriously, tracking your utility expenses month by month can reveal some pretty interesting trends. You can spot spikes and dips, identify potential issues (like my mum’s A-C addiction!), and ultimately, find ways to save money.

unnormalised: Another thing is to always pay the bills on time. Nothing worse than late fees, especially when those fees are like 2% of the total bill amount. Nobody wants to pay extra money for something they've already used!
normalised: Another thing is to always pay the bills on time. Nothing worse than late fees, especially when those fees are like two percent of the total bill amount. Nobody wants to pay extra money for something they've already used!

unnormalised: So, yeah, that's my little rant about utility bills. Remember to stay vigilant, compare plans, and keep track of your expenses. It might not be the most exciting topic, but it's definitely an important one. Happy saving, guys! :)
normalised: So, yeah, that's my little rant about utility bills. Remember to stay vigilant, compare plans, and keep track of your expenses. It might not be the most exciting topic, but it's definitely an important one. Happy saving, guys!
